yaml.description: WeasyPrint is a **powerful and easy-to-use library** for generating PDFs from HTML and CSS in Django. It provides **better styling control** than reportlab and is well-suited for **dynamic PDF generation** (e.g., invoices, reports, and receipts).
yaml.title: PDF Generation

markdown.headingText: **üöÄ Step-by-Step Guide to Using WeasyPrint in Django**
markdown.markdown:
### **1Ô∏è‚É£ Install WeasyPrint** Before using WeasyPrint, install it using `pip`: ```bash pip install weasyprint ``` WeasyPrint has some system dependencies. If you face installation issues, install the required system packages: For **Ubuntu/Debian**: ```bash sudo apt install libpango-1.0-0 libpangocairo-1.0-0 libcairo2 libffi-dev ``` For **MacOS**: ```bash brew install pango cairo gdk-pixbuf ``` For **Windows**: - Install GTK+ from [WeasyPrint's documentation](https://doc.courtbouillon.org/weasyprint/stable/first_steps.html). --- ### **2Ô∏è‚É£ Create a Django View to Generate PDFs** We will create a **class-based view** (`WeasyTemplateResponseMixin`) to render a Django template into a PDF. #### **üìå Example: Generating a Simple PDF** ```python # views.py from django.http import HttpResponse from django.template.loader import get_template from weasyprint import HTML import tempfile def generate_pdf(request): """ Generate a simple PDF from an HTML template. """ template = get_template("pdf_template.html") context = {"title": "My PDF Report", "content": "This is a dynamically generated PDF."} html_content = template.render(context) # Create a temporary file with tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile(delete=True) as temp_file: HTML(string=html_content).write_pdf(temp_file.name) temp_file.seek(0) pdf_data = temp_file.read() response = HttpResponse(pdf_data, content_type="application/pdf") response["Content-Disposition"] = 'inline; filename="report.pdf"' return response ``` --- ### **3Ô∏è‚É£ Create an HTML Template for the PDF** WeasyPrint **renders HTML and CSS**, so we need to define a well-structured HTML template. #### **üìå Example: `pdf_template.html`** ```html {{ title }}

{{ title }}

{{ content }}

``` --- ### **4Ô∏è‚É£ Add URL Pattern** Map the PDF generation view in `urls.py`: ```python # urls.py from django.urls import path from .views import generate_pdf urlpatterns = [ path("generate-pdf/", generate_pdf, name="generate_pdf"), ] ``` Now, visiting **`/generate-pdf/`** will return a dynamically generated PDF. --- ## **üñãÔ∏è Advanced WeasyPrint Usage** ### **1Ô∏è‚É£ Generating PDFs with Django Querysets** You can **pass database query results** into the PDF template. #### **üìå Example: Generating a PDF Invoice** ```python # views.py from django.http import HttpResponse from django.template.loader import render_to_string from weasyprint import HTML from .models import Order def generate_invoice(request, order_id): """ Generate an invoice PDF for a specific order. """ order = Order.objects.get(id=order_id) context = {"order": order} html_string = render_to_string("invoice_template.html", context) pdf_file = HTML(string=html_string).write_pdf() response = HttpResponse(pdf_file, content_type="application/pdf") response["Content-Disposition"] = f'filename="invoice_{order.id}.pdf"' return response ``` #### **üìå Example: `invoice_template.html`** ```html Invoice

Invoice for Order #{{ order.id }}

Customer: {{ order.customer_name }}

Date: {{ order.date }}

{% for item in order.items.all %} {% endfor %}
Product Quantity Price
{{ item.product_name }} {{ item.quantity }} ${{ item.price }}

Total Amount: ${{ order.total_price }}

``` --- ### **2Ô∏è‚É£ Saving PDFs to Django Models** You can **store generated PDFs** as files inside a Django model. #### **üìå Example: Save Invoice as a File** ```python from django.core.files.base import ContentFile from weasyprint import HTML from .models import Order def save_invoice_pdf(order_id): """ Generate and save a PDF invoice to a model field. """ order = Order.objects.get(id=order_id) html_string = render_to_string("invoice_template.html", {"order": order}) pdf_file = HTML(string=html_string).write_pdf() # Save to model order.invoice.save(f"invoice_{order.id}.pdf", ContentFile(pdf_file), save=True) ``` #### **üìå Update `Order` Model** ```python from django.db import models class Order(models.Model): customer_name = models.CharField(max_length=100) date = models.DateField(auto_now_add=True) total_price = models.DecimalField(max_digits=10, decimal_places=2) invoice = models.FileField(upload_to="invoices/", blank=True, null=True) # Store PDF ``` --- ## **üé® Styling PDFs with CSS** WeasyPrint **fully supports CSS**, including: ‚úÖ Fonts ‚úÖ Page Breaks ‚úÖ Headers & Footers ‚úÖ Images #### **üìå Example: Adding Page Breaks** ```css @page { size: A4; margin: 20mm; } .page-break { page-break-before: always; } ``` #### **üìå Usage in HTML** ```html

Page 1 content

Page 2 content

``` --- ## **üìå Common WeasyPrint Issues & Fixes** | **Issue** | **Solution** | |-----------|-------------| | `no such file or directory: cairo` | Install dependencies: `sudo apt install libcairo2` | | `No module named weasyprint` | Run `pip install weasyprint` | | Fonts not loading | Use absolute file paths for fonts (`file://` URLs) | --- ## **‚úÖ Summary: Key Takeaways** | **Feature** | **Django Implementation** | |------------|---------------------------| | ‚úÖ Generate PDFs | `HTML(string).write_pdf()` | | ‚úÖ Use Templates | `render_to_string("template.html", context)` | | ‚úÖ Save PDFs to Models | `order.invoice.save(...)` | | ‚úÖ Style with CSS | Full CSS support, including `@page` | üöÄ **Now you can generate beautifully styled PDFs in Django using WeasyPrint!** üöÄ

## **üöÄ Step-by-Step Guide to Using WeasyPrint in Django** ### **1Ô∏è‚É£ Install WeasyPrint** Before using WeasyPrint, install it using `pip`: ```bash pip install weasyprint ``` WeasyPrint has some system dependencies. If you face installation issues, install the required system packages: For **Ubuntu/Debian**: ```bash sudo apt install libpango-1.0-0 libpangocairo-1.0-0 libcairo2 libffi-dev ``` For **MacOS**: ```bash brew install pango cairo gdk-pixbuf ``` For **Windows**: - Install GTK+ from [WeasyPrint's documentation](https://doc.courtbouillon.org/weasyprint/stable/first_steps.html). --- ### **2Ô∏è‚É£ Create a Django View to Generate PDFs** We will create a **class-based view** (`WeasyTemplateResponseMixin`) to render a Django template into a PDF. #### **üìå Example: Generating a Simple PDF** ```python # views.py from django.http import HttpResponse from django.template.loader import get_template from weasyprint import HTML import tempfile def generate_pdf(request): """ Generate a simple PDF from an HTML template. """ template = get_template("pdf_template.html") context = {"title": "My PDF Report", "content": "This is a dynamically generated PDF."} html_content = template.render(context) # Create a temporary file with tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile(delete=True) as temp_file: HTML(string=html_content).write_pdf(temp_file.name) temp_file.seek(0) pdf_data = temp_file.read() response = HttpResponse(pdf_data, content_type="application/pdf") response["Content-Disposition"] = 'inline; filename="report.pdf"' return response ``` --- ### **3Ô∏è‚É£ Create an HTML Template for the PDF** WeasyPrint **renders HTML and CSS**, so we need to define a well-structured HTML template. #### **üìå Example: `pdf_template.html`** ```html {{ title }}

{{ title }}

{{ content }}

``` --- ### **4Ô∏è‚É£ Add URL Pattern** Map the PDF generation view in `urls.py`: ```python # urls.py from django.urls import path from .views import generate_pdf urlpatterns = [ path("generate-pdf/", generate_pdf, name="generate_pdf"), ] ``` Now, visiting **`/generate-pdf/`** will return a dynamically generated PDF. --- ## **üñãÔ∏è Advanced WeasyPrint Usage** ### **1Ô∏è‚É£ Generating PDFs with Django Querysets** You can **pass database query results** into the PDF template. #### **üìå Example: Generating a PDF Invoice** ```python # views.py from django.http import HttpResponse from django.template.loader import render_to_string from weasyprint import HTML from .models import Order def generate_invoice(request, order_id): """ Generate an invoice PDF for a specific order. """ order = Order.objects.get(id=order_id) context = {"order": order} html_string = render_to_string("invoice_template.html", context) pdf_file = HTML(string=html_string).write_pdf() response = HttpResponse(pdf_file, content_type="application/pdf") response["Content-Disposition"] = f'filename="invoice_{order.id}.pdf"' return response ``` #### **üìå Example: `invoice_template.html`** ```html Invoice

Invoice for Order #{{ order.id }}

Customer: {{ order.customer_name }}

Date: {{ order.date }}

{% for item in order.items.all %} {% endfor %}
Product Quantity Price
{{ item.product_name }} {{ item.quantity }} ${{ item.price }}

Total Amount: ${{ order.total_price }}

``` --- ### **2Ô∏è‚É£ Saving PDFs to Django Models** You can **store generated PDFs** as files inside a Django model. #### **üìå Example: Save Invoice as a File** ```python from django.core.files.base import ContentFile from weasyprint import HTML from .models import Order def save_invoice_pdf(order_id): """ Generate and save a PDF invoice to a model field. """ order = Order.objects.get(id=order_id) html_string = render_to_string("invoice_template.html", {"order": order}) pdf_file = HTML(string=html_string).write_pdf() # Save to model order.invoice.save(f"invoice_{order.id}.pdf", ContentFile(pdf_file), save=True) ``` #### **üìå Update `Order` Model** ```python from django.db import models class Order(models.Model): customer_name = models.CharField(max_length=100) date = models.DateField(auto_now_add=True) total_price = models.DecimalField(max_digits=10, decimal_places=2) invoice = models.FileField(upload_to="invoices/", blank=True, null=True) # Store PDF ``` --- ## **üé® Styling PDFs with CSS** WeasyPrint **fully supports CSS**, including: ‚úÖ Fonts ‚úÖ Page Breaks ‚úÖ Headers & Footers ‚úÖ Images #### **üìå Example: Adding Page Breaks** ```css @page { size: A4; margin: 20mm; } .page-break { page-break-before: always; } ``` #### **üìå Usage in HTML** ```html

Page 1 content

Page 2 content

``` --- ## **üìå Common WeasyPrint Issues & Fixes** | **Issue** | **Solution** | |-----------|-------------| | `no such file or directory: cairo` | Install dependencies: `sudo apt install libcairo2` | | `No module named weasyprint` | Run `pip install weasyprint` | | Fonts not loading | Use absolute file paths for fonts (`file://` URLs) | --- ## **‚úÖ Summary: Key Takeaways** | **Feature** | **Django Implementation** | |------------|---------------------------| | ‚úÖ Generate PDFs | `HTML(string).write_pdf()` | | ‚úÖ Use Templates | `render_to_string("template.html", context)` | | ‚úÖ Save PDFs to Models | `order.invoice.save(...)` | | ‚úÖ Style with CSS | Full CSS support, including `@page` | üöÄ **Now you can generate beautifully styled PDFs in Django using WeasyPrint!** üöÄ

metadata.description: WeasyPrint is a **powerful and easy-to-use library** for generating PDFs from HTML and CSS in Django. It provides **better styling control** than reportlab and is well-suited for **dynamic PDF generation** (e.g., invoices, reports, and receipts).
